advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Doctors, it gonna cure your work" <br><br> "ITT 3030, the absolute intelligence"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (NOV. 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The advert says that 37 cartridges are already available and that a BASIC programming cartridge is on the way (though it will never make it to the shelves). <br><br> The advert also clearly says that the system comes from America and that it offers Arcade Hits at home.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.primo.homeserver.hu/" target="_blank">PRIMO home-page</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> THE PERSONABLE COMPUTER</strong></font><br><blockquote>January 1983<br> Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> What's a personable computer? It's a computer with business application versatility at personal computer price. It's a computer powerful enough to tackle even your toughest business jobs, yet at a price that wont put you out of business...</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT, OCT 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>Notice that the pictured floppy drives have never been released.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT (1986)</strong></font><br><blockquote>November 1986 price list:<br> Monochrome - Single drive: <b>£399</b> + VAT<br> Monochrome - Dual drive: <b>£499</b> + VAT<br> Colour - Single drive: <b>£549</b> + VAT<br> Colour - Dual drive: <b>£649</b> + VAT<br><br> Optional 10 MB hard disk: <b>£300</b> + VAT </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is the home version of the Goupil 3, with only RGB video output and cassette interface. <br><br> What a lucky girl ! Her father offered her a fantastic game machine (the game pictured here must be the only one available for the Goupil 3). This system is perfectly adapted to her small fingers and so delicate knees (have a look at this enormous keyboard, man !).<br> The father must have been working for S.M.T. (manufacturer of the Goupil), as I don't see any other logical explanation. No one would have made this to his child without fearing eternal reproaches.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NEW ZEALAND ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>From left to right arrow, advert says:<br><font color="#666666"> Redesigned front panel. Totally synchronous logic design. Same switch and LED arrangement as original Altair 8800. New back.lit Duralith (laminated plastic and mylar, bonded to aluminum) dress panel with multi.color graphics. New longer, flat toggle switches. Five new functions stored on front panel PROM inc1uding: DISPLAY ACCUMULATOR (displays contents of accumulator), LOAD ACCUMULATOR (loads contents of the 8 data switches (A7.AO) into accumulator), OUTPUT ACCUMULATOR (Outputs contents of accumulator to I/O device addressed by the upper 8 address switches), INPUT ACCUMULATOR (inputs to the accumulator from the I/O device), and SLOW (causes program execution at a rate of about 5 cycles per second for program debugging). <br><br> Two, 34 conductor ribbon cable assemblies. Connects front panel board to front panel interface board. Eliminates need for complicated front panel/bus wiring. <br><br> New front panel interface board buffers all lines to and from 8800b bus. <br><br> Rugged, commercial grade Optima cabinet. <br><br> Full 18 slot motherboard. <br><br> New CPU board with 8080A microprocessor and Intel 8224 clock generator and 8216 bus drivers. Clock pulse widths and phasing as well as frequency are crystal controlled. Compatible with all current Altair 8800 software and hardware!. <br><br> New, heavy duty power supply: +8 volts at 18 amps, + 18 volts at 2 amps, -18 volts at 2 amps. 110 volt or 220 volt operation (50/60 Hz). Primary tapped for either high or low line operation.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Murray Moffatt</b> from New Zealand</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> M-SERIES BROCHURE - PAGE 1-2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Juraj Mucko for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> COMPUTER NOTES</strong></font><br><blockquote>This fanzine - one of the first of the microcomputers era - was published by the Altair User Group<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Mark Thompson</b> </p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 3 PAGE U.S. ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>First HX-20 U.S. advert (september 1982)<br><br> Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">The size, of course, is a dead giveaway. But don't let the size fool you. The HX-20 is not a toy. Or a glorified calculator.<br> It's a computer.<br> A real computer with 16K RAM<br>...<br> Surprised that a computer like the HX-20 should come from Epson?<br> You shouldn't be. Because we have been building computers in Japan since 1978. And we have been practicing ultra-high-quality precision manufacturing for a lot longer than that.<br><br> We didn't jump right into the American microcomputer market. We could afford to bide our time; to wait for the product that was going to stand America on its ears.<br> This is it.<br> The Epson HX-20</font></blockquote>

computer.description:
Very little information about this Bulgarian mainframe used by big East European companies as an industrial or information management system.
It was partially compatible with IBM mainframe and could also share programs and data with the russian Minsk-32. It could run in multiprogram mode thanks to its virtual memory.
The ISOT brand name means 'State Economic Alliance'
Thanks to Bojidar Stefanov for information and picture.
computer.graphics: Graphic capabilities with some ISOT video terminals
computer.media: Magnetic tapes. Recording speed of 120 KB per sec.
computer.name: EC-1035
computer.peripherals: I/O Multiplexer ISOT 8401 for serial and Parallel peripherals
computer.ram: 256 to 512 KB. 16 MB virtual memory max.

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> OTHER ISOT SYSTEMS</strong></font><br><blockquote>ISOT also made several 8-bit and 16-bit desktop computers, among them:<br> • <b>1030C</b> 8086 based CAD system<br> • <b>1031C</b> Z80 - CP/M system<br> • <b>1039C</b> (also named CM-4) 16-bit multitasking system<br> • <b>1036C</b> PC compatible system based on the Bulgarian CM688 processor, compatible with the Intel 8088. Here pictured with the <b>ISOT 6305C</b> 132-col. 150 cps dot-matrix printer.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Bojidar Stefanov</b></p></blockquote>
